div.head: Regarding the text
div.p:
Iam de voluntate
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 45, c. 1
, etc. After the Master considered the knowledge and power of God, in this distinction 45 he begins to treat about the divine will. And he divides the discussion into two sections because in the first place he offers something like description of the divine will, then in the second place he adds many definitions of the divine will. The second part is begins at
hoc est praetereundum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 45, c. 5
.

The first part is divided into two because in the first place he shows what the divine will is, in the second place he shows how it is the cause of all things. The second part begins at,
haec itaque summa bona
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 45, c. 4
, etc. And this is the general division of the present distinction about which the following question is introduced.

div.head: Question
div.p: Whether through the strength of the divine will all things are ordered and regulated for the beauty of the universe; whether through the rectitude of the divine will all things are ordered for the beauty of the universe.

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p:
That not because, if through the strength of the divine will all things etc, then however much resistance a moveable thing would be increased and created potency would be diminished; motion on account of this would never be diminished. The consequent is false as is known from experience. And the consequences is clear because the total moving potency in moving and causing infinitely exceeds the total resistance. This is confirmed because then for the doubling of a created mover there would never be a doubling of the speed or of the moveable thing. The consequent is against the rules of the
Philosopher, in book VII of the Physics
Aristoteles, Physica VII, xx
and is against experience. And the consequence is clear because the total proportion or excess of the mover to the resistence of the moveable thing is not able to be doubled, indeed the total moving potency infinitely exceeds the resistive potency of the moveable thing.

In the second place, if the divine willing sufficiently regulated everytying, it would follow that every active regulation of someone else would be superfluous. The consequent is false because, when God regulates and orders every cause regulating something, it follows that God would do something in vain. But the consequence is clear since the divine willing by itself would be able to regulate equally well. This is confirmed because with respect to two things drawing a ship if one draws and moves more strongly into infinity than the other, it follows that the second contributes nothing to the motion. This is clear because when this second force is ruled out and removed there will be no change regarding the motion of the other; the ship will be moved with the same speed as before.

In the third place, it would be better that bad things do not exist than for them to exist in the universe, therefore the divine will does not regulate for the beauty of the universe. The antecedent is clear because
evil is a corruption of the good
Augustine Confessions VII, 4, 6
according to
Augustine in many places . Again, evil does not perfect nature damages and weakens and takes away from the good. The consequence is clear because a good organizer and regulator always ought to regulate for and do what is better, therefore.

In opposition is the
Apostle, in Romans 11 ,
all things are through him and from him and in him
Romans 11:36 . Again,
First Corinthians 7
God does all things in everyone
I Corinthinas 12:6 . To this is
Augustine, 2o City of God chapter 18 and 23
Augustinus, De Civitate Dei xxx
, where he declares how beauty of the whole results from contraries and many differences conveniently arranged, for example the blackness of the pupil in the image if it were considered in itself it seems to be ugly rather than beautiful, nevertheless when related to the other parts of the eye and face it beautifies the image. Again, a a think and ruddy voice by itself is not considered sweet and delightful, nevertheless when related to another voice as a tenor it constitutes a harmony and sweet melody, therefore.

div.head: Conclusion 1
div.p:
First conclusion: the divine will regulates and orders every real and positive entity through a productive ratio. This is clear through
Augustine, 12 City of God, in chapter 16 , who says
the hidden power of God penetrating all things in some make makes everything that is inasmuch as it is
Augustine, City of God XII, 26
. Again,
Anselm, De Concordia
Anselmus, De Concordia xxx
and
On Free Will, near the end
Anselm, On Free Will xxx
says
in all volitions and good works God makes both those which are in essence and are good, but in bad things he does make that which is bad, but only those which are through an essence This is confirmed by reason because in the essential order of effective causes the posterior acts because of the causality of the first cause. But God is the first cause in the essential order of effective causes according to theologians and philosophers, therefore any second cause depends on and presupposes the causality of God in its being and its action.

First corollary: the doubling of any mover or the total moving caused is not always required for the doubling of the moved or the real action. This is clear because the divine power is not able to be doubled, and nevertheless he moves and acts in any action of the created agent as the conclusion says, therefore.

The second corollary: though fire is an effect of a natural agent or in a natural activity, nevertheless any effect is able to be called free inasmuch as it has been produced by an immeasurable liberty. The first is clear because fire is produced by natural causes alone albeit with the general influence of God. The second also is clear because any effect depends more on God causing freely than on any second causes.

Third corollary: though no finite cause is sufficient for completely producing even the smallest effect, nevertheless no created effect is formally of infinite difficulty or resistance for being produced. The first part is clear because for the production of any effect immeasurable divine activity is required, therefore. The second part is proved because the production of one effect is of greater difficulty than the production of another, therefore. Again for any given or giveable difficulty or resistance a greater difficulty is able to be given, and this applies in the case of second causes because with respect to the first there is no difficult or resistance, therefore.

Corollary: though no divine willing short of effective is executive, nevertheless the divine permission ought not to be called remitted. This is clear because remission or being remitted indicates and imperfection, contra
Scotus, distinction 27 of book 1 (or 37)
Scotus, I, d. 27 .

Another corollary: though in God there is a single simple willing, nevertheless according to one and then another respect he effects a produced entity and obligates the created mind. The first is clear because God is a single simple thing. The second part is clear because he obligates as a command and does not effect as a command.

div.head: Conclusion 2
div.p: Second conclusion: though not everything that occurs in some way occurs from the approval or pleasure of the divine will, nevertheless the divine will wills anything producible externally willed by God by an immeasurable indifference. The first part is apparent from sin, concerning which, if it is true that it occurs, nevertheless God gives not approval nor wishes any positive efficacy, rather he only wills that it should be permitted. The second part is proved because will externally with an immeasurable freedom, therefore he is immeasurably indifferent. The consequence is clear because, if he is not immeasurably indifferent, it follows that by willing externally he would lose some degree of freedom, which should not be said.

The first corollary: just anything thing internally producible is proposed to the divine will with equal indifference, so anything existing externally in itself is immediately determined to the divine will in its own actual being. This is clear because, if it were not able to go into act through its own external willing with an equal indifference, then it follows that it is not truly but falsely, proposed that it would be possible internally for itself, which is false.

Second corollary: to every positive thing concurs the divine intellect, representing ideally, and the divine will , being disposed with respect to this thing or being able to be disposed productively or causally. this is clear because according to
Augustine, II Confessions, in chapter 7
, God
does what he does by no means other than by saying
Augustinus, Confessionum XI, c. 7, n. 9
. But whatever he wishes he wishes in an equally primary way, and he does speaks, therefore these powers concur in an equally primary way, etc.

Third corollary: just divine willing immediately produces every positive effect, so it touches every effect immediately, causally, and illatively without distinction. The first part is clear through what has been said in the first conclusion. Again, it is clear through
Blessed Augustine, I De Trinitate, chapter 15 , where he says,
there is not any nature even in the smallest and lowests beasts which he did not constitute, from whom is every motion, every order, every species without which nothing is able to be discovered or thought
Augustinus, De civitate Dei XI, 15
. The second part is proved because with respect to any external effect the divine willing is disposed in an equally primary way, as it has been said. But it immediately, causally, illatively touches some effect, therefore it immediately touches any effect otherwise one would be before the other, and they would not be equally primary.

From the first part fo the conclusion it follows that the volitional ratio does not correspond to everything to which the causal effective ratio corresponds. This is clear because according to the
Master, in distinction 45
Lombardus, Sent. I, 45, c. 7
, the volitional ratio corresponds to permission and the effective ratio does not. And through this are solved many arguments of
Bradwardine
XXX
.

div.head: Conclusion 3
div.p:
Third conclusion: though no evil of guilt is able to become good absolutely, per se, and directly, nevertheless God orders all external things freely for the beauty of the universe, decently, and perfectly. The first part is clear through
Augustine in many places , saying that,
evil is a privation of the good
. But the privation of the good is not per se and absolutely good or a good privation, therefore. Again, this is confirmed because when a evil thing occurs or is done this does not produce something good but detracts from the good. The second part is clear through the
Master, in distinction 45, in that chapter that begins permissio autem etc
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 45, c. xxx
. Again, it would be able to be confirmed through
example of Augustine introduced in the affirmative part of the question
. Whence according to Augustine, God would not be allow evil things to be or come about unless he knew that good things would come from them.

First corollary: the ratio of the evil of guilt taken and produced in itself does not beautify the universe. This is clear because if this were the case then it would be good in itself for evil to be and to become, which is opposed to the conclusion.

The second conclusion: though it would be better in the universe that there was no evil, nevertheless by the just judgment of God the evils of guilt and penalty beautify the universe. The first is clear because, if not, then it follows that the state after sin would be more perfect by reason of its status considered in itself than before there was sin, which is false. And the consequence is clear since then there will be no evil. The argument clearly says by reason of its status considered in itself because the universe and its status is now more perfect on account of the fact that God was made man, but this is by reason of its status considered in itself. The second part is proved through
Augustine, XII De civitate, capitulo 7 vel vel 6 usque 24
Augustinus, De Civitate, XII, xxx . This is confirmed because by the just judgment of God
one sin will be the perpetual penalty of another.
Third corollary is responsive, namely the affirmative part of the question. This is clear through what has been said in the third conclusion.

div.head: Objections and responses
div.p: Against the first conclusion, it is argued in the first place because it would follows that God would influence and act for the conservation of b at the same time that he would be doing the same for it destruction. The consequent is false because then nothing would be able to be corrupted since the resistive power would be as great as the destructive power. But action does not come forth from a proportion of equality. The consequences is clear because, just as a creature is not able to act unless God is co-acting, so a creature is not able to resist unless God is co-resisting, and thus it further follows God would be resisting himself.

In the second place, it follows that no second cause will move in time but only in an instant. The consequent is counter to experience. And the consequence is clear because there will be no proportion of resistance to the total moving cause, indeed one of two moving causes exceeds the resistance of a movable thing ad infinitum.

In the third place, some created power is a sufficient moving cause of moveable b, therefore it is also a sufficient productive cause some effect. The consequence is clear from the terms. And the antecedent is proved because the resistance of moveable b is finite, therefore it is able to be exceeded and overcome by a finite power. But moving power exceeding the total resistance of some moveable thing suffices for moving something moveable without the help of another mover which is clear from the fact that since it exceeds the resistance it follows that the power moving is greater than moveable thing resisting.

In the fourth place, let it be put that a second cause ceases to move something moveable, that it was previously moving with the help of God, and that God uniformally continues his causality and motion with respect to moved b, then it is asked whether moved b will remain in motion or not. If the first, then the degree of causality and influence by God was previously causing was the total cause, and the second cause was contributing nothing. This is clear because the effect is posited through this causality by which this effect is posited while every other cause is uniformly and consistently is excluded. If the second is given, then either nothing of this moved b would be posited, and thus it follows that God would move and nothing would be moved, or some part of this moved b would be posited, and then it follows that the second cause has a certain share in the effect and God has another share, which is false.

Against the first part of the second conclusion with respect to any permitted things God has some act of will and does not have an act of non-volition, therefore it is an of act of volition. But a causal ratio corresponds to every divine volition, therefore, if God permitted sins, he wishes this causally and effectively.

In the second place against the second part, if this were so, it would follow that whatever is able to immediately non-will that same thing would be able to immediately will The consequent is false because one is able immediately to not will sins, but is not able to immediately wish them. But the consequences is clear because from the fact that there is equal indifference one is equally able to determine themselves to either option, therefore whatever one wishes they are able not to wish and vice versa.

In the third place, it follows that something intrinsic to God would suit an immeasurable difference in God and would be verified in God. The consequent is false because in this way some contingency would be intrinsic to God. And the consequence is clear because the divine willing instrinsic to God and the immeasurable divine is disposed to this in an external way, therefore.

In the fourth place, it follows that to intrinsic willing no external causality would entirely correspond. The consequent is false. And the consequence is clear because no
perfection corresponds to the divine will externally. But external causality is an immeasurable perfection in God, therefore external causality does not correspond to the divine willing. The minor is clear. The major is proved because any external willing of God, since it is able to not be, if it were called an intrinsic perfection in God then it would be possible for there to be an infinite perfection in God that is lacking which is impossible.

In the fifth place against the corollaries of this conclusion, it is argued because the executive power of God is more immediately disposed to external effects than the intellect and the will, therefore these powers do not in an equally primary way concur in producing a positive effect. The antecedent is proved because always understood and willed the world but did not always effect or produce it. Again,
Hugo, De sacramentis, in book one, in the second part, in chapter 5 , says,
that which he wished with a preceding will he completed with a subsequent power
Hugo de Sancto Victore De Sacramentis I, pars 2, c. 5
.

In the sixth place, after having posited an act of the will the effect is also posted, but this is not so in the case of the intellect, therefore the will is related more immediately than the intellect. This is the argument of
Thomae de Argentina, in the present distinction, in article 2
Thomas de Argentina, Sent. I, d. 45, a. 2 (Genoa 1585, f. 122r, ll. 66-68)
.

Against the third conclusion, God is not the regulative cause of those things of which he is the prohibitive cause. But God is the prohibitive cause of evil acts, therefore etc. The major is known and because the same thing being regulated and being prohibited at the same time by the same person seem to be contraries and out of touch with reason. The minor is known.

In the second place, if this were so, it follows that a divine prohibition would be a false sign and that God, in prohibiting and establishing, would be two-faced and feigning, having one thing in the will intrinsically and pretending to have another in the sign. The consequent is false. And the consequence is clear because when prohibiting something from occurring this signifies that he does not wish for it to occur. But if God wishes something to occur which he prohibits, then it follows that he does not prohibit this with the intention that it should not occur, therefore those doing the act are excused from guilt because they do not act against the intention of the legislator, indeed God would be contrary to his very self because he would act against his own intention and prohibition.

In the third place, because God is not wishing this action, therefore he is not wish this. The antecedent is proved because he hates this and punishes it and it is displeasing to him. But to hate and to be displeased is to not wish, therefore, just as to love and to please are types of willing.

In the fourth place, that is willed per se by God and is absolutely good which is the cause of the maximally good. But some bad therefore. The major is known because the effect is not superior to its cause. The minor is clear because the crucifixion and the death of Christ was the cause of our liberation and redemption, and nevertheless crucifixion itself was bad because otherwise the Jews would not have sinned. Again, the sin of Adae was the cause of the incarnation according to some saints, whence
Gregory
says
O happy guilt Gregrius Magnus, xxx .

In the fifth place, evil does occur, therefore God wishes evil to occur. The consequence holds because, since the will of God is omnipotent, it follows that it is impossible for something to occur that God does not want to occur.

In the sixth place, God wishes the suffering of the saints, therefore he wishes everything without which these sufferings are not able to be or occur . The consequence is clear because one wishing an end also wishes those things which includes the persecution of these saints, as part of the pursuit them. Again, God wishes the antecedent which is that the saints earn merit through these sufferings, therefore he wishes the consequent
which is the unjust persecution of the saints because this consequent is included in the antecedent.

To the first, the consequent is able to be conceded because it is not inconvenient with respect to an illicit power and resistance without the help of a general influence which helps and resists one and the same thing by reason of diverse things in which influences at the same time, just as the sun assists two competing things at least in the act of illuminating, and nevertheless the sun resists each and impedes each by the fact that it helps each. Similarly, I am able to assist the same thing by lifting the load over the head and impede at the same time by adding weight.

In the second place, it would be able to be said that God principally and directly helps this second cause, but secondarily and indirectly resists it. Therefore properly and per se he does not resists himself just as the sun when it dries and hardens clay and at the same time melts the nearby ice the melting of which impedes the condensing and the hardening of the clay.

To the second, the consequence is denied, and to the proof it is said that, though there is no proportion of resistance to the power of the first cause insofar as it is omnipotent and infinite, nevertheless there is a proportion to the total particular moving power, and this suffices with the general influence for a determinate speed what is moved.

Note that willing and non-willing in God is the same simple act under different names on account of its diverse effects and various respects, and this does not seem inconvenient since those who deny non-willing in God posit the same potency to be called free and necessary according to various respects, therefore by the same reason the same willing on account of a different respect is able to be called non-willing.

In the second place, it is able to be said that the proportion of resistance to the total moving power is not according to that which is essentially nor according to that which is power absolutely, but as it tends toward being changed according to the order instituted by God.

To the third, the antecedent is denied. To the proof it is said it is said that to move b the power exceeding the resistance of moveable b is not sufficient with respect to cause. And if it is conceded consequently that a is more able to move in the order of a particular mover than b is able to resist, nevertheless this is only true having supposed the concurrence and help of the essentially preordained cause.

To the fourth, it is said that motion b will remain, but from this it does not follows that God would first be the total cause and that the second cause would contribute nothing because, though the divine willing is sufficient for positing the total effect, nevertheless from his own liberty he is able to allow within himself another causality for the same effect.
To the first against the second conclusion, the major is denied. And to the proof, the consequences is denied because he would no less wisely govern the universe if there were no sin.

To the second, the consequence is denied because the reason of indifference is not terminated nor does it consider contraries as extremes, just willing and nilling (nolens) are but rather contradictories, as willing and not willing (non volens) are.

In the second place, it would be able to be said that whatever is able to wish externally, he is able to nil (nolle) externally, but not the converse. The reason is because whatever God is able to will externally, he is able not to will (non velle), and whatever he is able not to will (non velle), he is able to nil (nolle). Nevertheless he is not able to will whatever he is able not to will (non velle) or nil (nolle) because then he would be able to will sin.

To the third, it is said that the consequent is able to be taken in two ways. In the first mode intrinsically and entitatively, and thus the consequence is denied. In a second mode extrinsically through a denotive disposition,
and in this way the antecedent is conceded, nor does this put properly put intrinsic contingency in God unlesss contingency is understood indifferently as the contingency of liberty, just those who posit contingency in God perhaps understand the term.

To the fourth, the consequence is denied. And when it is proved,
because no perfection corresponds , etc., this is denied, but it is indeed able to be called non willing (non velle) externally. Nevertheless what has been proposed does not follow from this.

To the fifth, the consequence is deneid because it is not necessary to posit another power on account of this, and another respect of the same powers To the saying of Hugh, it is said that there he speaks about the mode which is in us willing from this to lead us to the mystery of the trinity where this likeness falls short. And this itself is disclosed in the
prologue of the Angelic Hierarchy
XXX
.
To the sixth, the consequence is denied.

In the second place, it would be able to be said that the act of the divine intellect is the act of the divine will, therefore a diversity of acts is improperly posited there. Therefore if an act of the divine intellect is posited under some causal ratio of this creature, then the effect is equally well posited, just as if an act of the will were posited.

To the first against the third conclusion, the major would be able to be denied because when speaking about a positive act which is prohibited, through God regulate and coeffects and wills, nevertheless it should not be said that absolutely he wishes this to happen and be, but it should only be said secundum quid because he only has the will of general influence with the mixture of an involuntary. Think of the contrary wills of pre-ordination and an antecedent prohibition. Whence just like one throwing money into the sea, he does not wish to throw it absolutely, but rather prefers to live over riches. Similarly a father carrying the ship prohibits his son from carrying it, and nevertheless when the son carries it the father coacts, and nevertheless properly speaking the father the father does not wish that the son carries, indeed it displeases him, though he coacts in the same act, and nevertheless the son is not able to carry with the father, so God inasmuch as he from himself wishes that this not be posited. But if the created will truly wishes to posit this God does not withdraw his influence but relinquishes the will to its liberty, and thus it is produced. From this it is clear regarding these three arguments.

Nevertheless it for the matter and solution of the argument and what follows that God is said to wish something in various ways not because in the divine willing there is some intrinsic and formal difference, but rather this variety is formally in the formal denominations understood by the divine will. But this variety is in God virtually and equivallently.

\ In the first place therefore, with respect to some God has will in every mode of efficacy, and in this way he wills the world to be, and about this will it is said in
Romans 9 ,
For who resists his will?
Romanos 9:19 .

In the second place, with respect to other things he has a will of pre-ordained commands or guidelines, just as he wills this which he commands or advises, either that they come to be or no. And this is called the will of the sign, not because it is the divine will itself, but because it is a sign that God from himself wills and approves this to happen. And thus those things which happen against his commands are said to happen against his will.

In the third place, with respect to some things he has the will of approval and special acceptance or delight, and in this way he will
goods and merits which occur. See
Romans 12 ,
so that you may prove what is the good, pleasing, and perfect will of God
Romanos 12:2 . And this is able to be called absolutely the will of what is pleasing.
In the fourth place, with respect to some things he has the will of concession and licence, and thus he wills that somethings are licit or not illicit, as in the case of indifferent acts.
In the fifth place, with respect to some things he has the will of general influence or will of not subtracting influence, and this is called his will loosely and generally.

In the same way God would be able to be said to have a non wishing (nolle) with respect to diverse things. In the first place he does not will in effect, just as he does not will there to be another world.

In the second place, a non wishing of the antecedent of a prohibition or a contrary ordination, and in this way he wishes bad things to occur either that they become or they become or not. And through this the third argument is solved.

In the third place he has a non wishing of reprobation and special detestation and displeasure of the consequent, and in this way he wishes the bad things which occur. In this way it is said that he does not know evil ons, in
Matthew 25 ,
nescio vos
Matthaeus 25:12. .
In the fourth place he has the non wishing of negation and of the subtraction of influence, and in this way he is not wishing those things which are not.

From this it is clear which should be said to the three arguments. But how God with respect to those things which he reproves has in some mode a willing and in some mode a not willing (nolens) is clear in
I Sammuel 8 , for when the sons of Israel were begging for a king, the Lord said to Samuel, reproving him,
they have not rejected you, but me, that I should rule over them according to all their works
I Sam 8:7. , and in the same place God said,
hear their voice go and go make a king over them
I Sam 8:22. .

To the fourth, the antecedent is denied when taking the word cause loosely. To the proof, it is said that whatever is the case about a per se cause and univocal, in the proposed it is said that the were not the cause of our salvation per se and absolutely, but only occasionally and truly by accident, in the same way that frigidity is sometimes accidentally the cause of heat. Similarly it is able to be said that the sin of Adam was not the per se cause of our incarnation but only occasionally, though indeed according to the Master had Adam not sinned Christ would not have been incarnated

To the fifth, the consequence is denied. And to the proof, it is said that there are many things besides the will of God which are neither willed nor non-willed (nolita), but only permitted. Nor is it impossible for something to occur which God does not wish to occur, though it is impossible that something does not occur which he wishes to occur.

To the sixth, the consequence is denied. And to the proof, it is said when speaking uniformally about willing that God wills the suffering of the saints approvingly but does not will, except in a permissive way, that someone persecute them unjustly. And to the confirmation, it has been said above, but it is further said that he does not will the antecedent with his generality that is as something the consequent includes, but he only wishes the antecedent for his signified principle without his knowing inclusion.
To the first in the opposition, the consequence is denied. And to the proof, it is said that it does not proceed from a freely moving principle, but is moving naturally.

In the second place, in conformity what was previously said it is said that, though the moving power is total and infinite, nevertheless a particular created power is finite and according to the resistance or the intension of resistance with respect to this it is able to moved more or less intensely. To the confirmation, the consequence is denied, and it is said that for the doubling of the mover it is not necessary to double the universal cause which influences with a general influence in all causes, nor is the proportion of the velocity of the moved taken/understood according to the proportion of the resistance to such a power. But the total doubling of the particular created cause suffices. In the second place, it would be able to be said that it is not required that the second caused is doubled according to the absolute quiddity of his virtue/power because sometimes this naturally impossible. But it suffices that the proportion of the moving total particular power, such that it is moving and applied to the acting toward this affected or mobile thing.
In the third place, it would be able to be said that the rules of the
Philosopher VII Physics
Aristoteles, Physica VII, xx
would not hold in a free power with respect to an effect immediately proceeding from it. In the fourth place, it would be able to be said that, though formally and absolutely the divine concurrence or influence is doubled, nevertheless equivalently it is able to be said to be double in something similar.

To the second, the consequence is denied. And to the proof it is said that, though the divine willing by itself alone would equally perfectly regulate nevertheless it is more fitting that they are regulated through many things because it is more fitting that secondary causes have their own actions with their own capabilities than were they to lack these proper actions given to them by God. To the confirmation, it is clear through the same.

To the last argument, the antecedent is denied when understood in the divided sense, for he regulates the good and the bad either against his will or according to it, nevertheless against his will in one way and according to it in another as has been said above. And this suffices.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p:
Hic non est praetereundem
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
etc. Having posited a description of the will, here he considers a different understandig of it. And he divides this into three because first he considers the pleasing or effective will, in the second place he shows that the divine will on account of many signs is able to be called many things, and in the third place he shows that God perceives somethings which he does not wish to be fulfilled. The second begins at
aliquando vero secundum quamdam
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
. The third begins at
illa tria dicuntur dei voluntatis
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
, etc.

Iam de voluntate
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. xxx
. First conclusion: that the divine will is the divine essence, just as his essence is his knowledge. Whence the will in God does not indicate something effected or moved, as it does in us, but such things are not able to be in God, as has been said.
Second conclusion: though in God willing and being are the same, nevertheless God is not said to be all things which he knows, though in God knowing and being are the same.

Third conclusion: that
the will of God which is not able to be unjust or evil because God is eternal and unchangeable, though those things which are subjects to him are transient and vary
.

The fourth conclusion: that the will of God is the first and highest cause of all things,,
for this alone is, whence it has what has arisen whatever it is, but this has not arisen
. Therefore neither should its cause be sought because it would follow that there is something greater or prior to it, which is impious to believe.

Fifth conclusion: that the will of God is not unless it is one, and sometimes it is named please or a disposition, and it is not possible something that something occurs in opposition to this. But sometimes the signs of the divine will are called the will of God, just as the signs of anger are called anger and the signs of love are called love and this is a changing expression. But signs of the divine will are to command, to permit, to permit to counsel, to operate, or perception, prohibition, permission counsel, and operation. Whence what God commands is able to be called his will, and in the same way about the other signs. And it is possible for something to occur against these kinds of signs because God commands many and a variety of things which do not occur, just as when he commands Abraham to sacrifice his son,
and nevertheless he did not will the act of sacrifice but rather the will and obedience of Abraham and wished to prove and to show his faith. And in this way he commands and prohibits, permits, counsels, fulfills.
